articles.headline: Why Not Give Greeks Their Say?
articles.snippet: There is little reason to think that Greek citizens will be more cooperative in austerity now that it has been made clear their opinions are irrelevant to the people who run Europe.
articles.abstract: There is little reason to think that Greek citizens will be more cooperative in austerity now that it has been made clear their opinions are irrelevant to the people who run Europe.
articles.lead_paragraph: The fundamental nature of European governance is about to change.

articles.headline: Bank of America Plans Stock Swap to Cut Debt
articles.snippet: Nearly $3 billion in new stock is likely to replace preferred shares, officials say, but they insist there is no shortfall in capital.
articles.abstract: Nearly $3 billion in new stock is likely to replace preferred shares, officials say, but they insist there is no shortfall in capital.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bank of America has developed a plan to issue nearly $3 billion in common stock to raise capital and reduce debt, changing course after saying for months that it did not intend to sell new shares.

articles.headline: Bleak Portrait of Poverty Is Off the Mark, Experts Say
articles.snippet: The Census Bureau will release a long-promised alternate measure meant to do a better job of counting the resources of the needy and bills they have to pay.
articles.abstract: The Census Bureau will release a long-promised alternate measure meant to do a better job of counting the resources of the needy and bills they have to pay.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When the Census Bureau said in September that the number of poor Americans had soared by 10 million to rates rarely seen in four decades, commentators called the report “shocking” and “bleak.” Most poverty experts would add another description: “flawed.”
articles.byline: By Jason DeParle, Robert Gebeloff and Sabrina Tavernise

articles.headline: For Perry, Private Jets Have Been Key to Public Job
articles.snippet: Gov. Rick Perry of Texas is far from alone in accepting air travel from executives and donors. But his reliance on the flights to perform government functions stands out.
articles.abstract: Gov. Rick Perry of Texas is far from alone in accepting air travel from executives and donors. But his reliance on the flights to perform government functions stands out.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a July morning in 2008, Gov. Rick Perry of Texas and several aides boarded a plane for Washington to lobby on ethanol use, an issue important to corn growers and livestock owners in his state.

articles.headline: Oversight of Brokers Scrutinized
articles.snippet: Questions about the adequacy of regulation of midlevel finanical companies have taken greater urgency following MF Global’s failure and the plunge in shares of the Jefferies Group.
articles.abstract: Questions about the adequacy of regulation of midlevel finanical companies have taken greater urgency following MF Global’s failure and the plunge in shares of the Jefferies Group.
articles.lead_paragraph: Who was in charge of regulating MF Global?
articles.byline: By Louise Story and Eric Dash

articles.headline: Greek Leader Survives Vote, Bolstering Deal on Europe Debt
articles.snippet: Prime Minister George Papandreou made it through a confidence vote in Parliament and met with President Karolos Papoulias to explore the composition of a transitional government.
articles.abstract: Prime Minister George Papandreou made it through a confidence vote in Parliament and met with President Karolos Papoulias to explore the composition of a transitional government.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Prime Minister George Papandreou of Greece survived a crucial confidence vote in the Greek Parliament early on Saturday, a vote that signaled approval of the comprehensive deal reached by European leaders last week to stabilize the euro and to help Greece avoid defaulting on its debt.

articles.headline: U.S. Adds a Modest 80,000 Jobs; Rate Drops to 9%
articles.snippet: The American unemployment rate dipped to 9 percent, but the improvement, slightly less than what economists had expected, was seen as mediocre.
articles.abstract: The American unemployment rate dipped to 9 percent, but the improvement, slightly less than what economists had expected, was seen as mediocre.
